qas.question: How common are variations in text that alter the meaning of the Urtext of the Hebrew Bible?
To what degree do variations in the Old Testament alter the meaning?
Who claims that the Old Testament is essentially the same throughout all variations?
How many variations of the Old Testament offer the same meaning?
What book did Douglas Stuart summarize?
How many of the textual variants are significant?
How many variants change the doctrine considerably?
Stuart thought the Bible is largely different because of what?

context: Shemaryahu Talmon, who summarized the amount of consensus and genetic relation to the Urtext of the Hebrew Bible, concluded that major divergences which intrinsically affect the sense are <a0_0>extremely rare<a0_0/>. As far as the Hebrew Bible referenced by Old Testament is concerned, <b5_0><b6_0>almost all<b6_0/><b5_0/> of the textual variants are fairly insignificant and <a1_0>hardly affect any doctrine<a1_0/>. <a2_0>Professor Douglas Stuart<a2_0/> states: "It is fair to say that the verses, chapters, and books of the <b4_0>Bible<b4_0/> would read largely the same, and would leave the same impression with the reader, even if one adopted <a3_0>virtually every possible alternative reading<a3_0/> to those now serving as the basis for current <b7_0>English translations<b7_0/>."
